title: What’s hot for Kiwi cruisers
text:
What’s hot for Kiwi cruisers sponsored SPONSORED CONTENT BY CRUISEABOUT Last updated 05:00, July 14 2015 CRUISEABOUT/SUPPLIED 
River cruises through Europe are more in demand than ever before. 
Figures from the latest Cruise Lines International Association (CLIA) Cruise Industry Source Market Report show that the number of New Zealand cruisers has more than doubled in the last seven years, with the market experiencing an annual average increase of 14 per cent. 
Cruiseabout NZ brand leader Danny Bodgers says the continuing demand for cruise holidays is largely due to increasing competition, consumer confidence, affordability and the variety of cruise holidays available. 
"Cruising is New Zealand's fastest growing tourism sector and is fast becoming a staple holiday option for locals of all ages." 
Bodger says the increasing number of cruise ships stopping at New Zealand ports means some lines are tailoring their onboard offerings to suit the Kiwi market – changing menus, adding more sun protection and including tipping in upfront costs. 
"We are seeing cruises that have added lamb to their menu and even had their baristas spend time at local cafes to get a taste for how we like our coffee," he says. 
Figures from CLIA showed the South Pacific as the destination of choice for Kiwis in 2015, attracting the biggest proportion of New Zealand passengers (31 per cent). 
Bodger says the current hot destinations for Cruiseabout NZ customers include Australia, the South Pacific, the Mediterranean, America and Asia. But there are a number of new destinations and cruising trends coming through as Kiwis look to cruise further afield. 
"River cruises through Europe and expedition cruises through the Galapagos Islands and Alaska are a lot more in demand than ever before. Destinations such as the Caribbean and the Baltic are also increasing in popularity," he says. 
More and more Kiwis are also opting to cruise around New Zealand with CLIA figures showing sailings in local waters accounted for a significant 53 per cent of all cruise holidays. 
Bodger says cruises are gaining popularity across all age groups. Ad Feedback 
"Expedition cruises in particular are increasingly appealing to the adventure seeker, both young and old. Island hopping cruises through the Pacific are popular with families, particularly those who can see the benefit of having onboard entertainment and a buffet for the kids!"
